pros: The staff are highly motivated and do their best to provide students with an education despite the efforts of administration. Also the students are usually very enthusiastic and eager to learn.
cons: The disadvantage is the administrative culture who see the university as a business or rather a scam to relieve students(' parents) and the provincial taxpayer of tuition monies and go through the motions of providing an education. Decisions affecting the university are not made on pedagogical merit, student interest or for the increase and dissemination of knowledge but for the profit margin. The treatment of part-time contract staff is deplorable.

review_title: Great culture at work, amazing benefits. The city and role just weren't for me
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Kitchener, ON
pros: Great benefits, full pension plan, health and dental coverage. Had 25 days of vacation in a senior analyst position is unheard of in the corporate world. All of the people I worked with were great overall. There are a couple of tough people to work with, but no more than anywhere really. Job stability and security are also benefits of the univsersity. Role advancement is available but you would have to be patient.
cons: Union environment can be a bit of a downer. A lot of "lifers" aren't very motivated to do anything beyond their job description.

review_title: Depends entirely on what you're doing and who you're working for
pros:
Was a Teaching Assistant here for a couple of terms; my experience was great because the professor I was working for was exceptional and gave me lots of responsibility that was commensurate with my level of experience and ability. She was just generally extremely enjoyable to work with and for. 

WLU, for the amount I interacted with the institution as an employee was just fine -- but basically,  I'm talking about the payroll department, because professors decide who their TAs will be and there's no interaction with HR (unless, I suppose, there's some kind of employment issue) and there was no real reason to interact with any other department. I would add, though, that since I was also a student here as well as an employee, that the Faculty of Graduate and Postgraduate Studies here is excellent; all the staff I interacted with in the grad studies office were great and very supportive.
cons: I didn't really experience any major cons, because my role was so limited. But I would expect that nature of one's experience working as a TA here (or at any institution) is almost wholly dependent on the professor(s) you work for. I guess the one thing I would say is that the quality of the students in the classes I supported (about 75-80 students each) was not impressive, on the whole; there were a handful of outstanding students, several truly terrible ones, and an inordinate number of average/barely average ones. WLU's entrance standards are way too low, and it screams cash grab. Enroll tons of first-year students, get all that tuition, and thin the herd by second year. But it makes for crappy academia (and overcrowded classrooms). However, the feeling one gets at WLU is that nothing matters more than the bottom line (not even school spirit, which runs a close second). Actual academic quality and standards are farther down the list.

pros: Great team, Great experience, Learned a lot about the school and about the recruitment process. Applying the skills to real life was very easy and it helped advance my career
cons: none. It is minimum wage pay but you don't do it for the pay. You do it for your passion for your school and to gain valuable experience that will help you through out your life

review_title: Great place to work and study.
pros: I learned a lot from my professor while working as RA. He always helped me whenever I need so. At times he acted as mentor and coach. As a student WLU is a great university to study. In general teachers are great in teaching and helping students.
cons: Few professors are not great in teaching the subject matters. However, they have the positive attitude to teach the students. The students standard are also not consistent.

pros: Laurier really is an exceptional place to work. I feel fortunate all the time to be employed here.
cons: I hate being part of the Union. I find we waste a lot of time being greedy from the University and it's at the cost of students ability to afford post-secondary educatio.

pros: Faculty are focused on being the best researchers and teachers in the country. Opportunities for teaching exist at three levels: bachelors, MA, and PhD.
cons: The campus appearance needs some attention because parking and auto traffic dominates and pedestrian traffic is often challenged. The winter climate is cold and can last up to six months.

review_title: Fun environment at the WLU Call Centre
job_title: Annaul Giving Representative in Waterloo, ON
pros: There's a lot of team building activities and supervisors have a group discussion to improve everyone's fundraising abilities. People are fairly friendly and you can get to know people easily due to the number of employees.
cons: The nature of the job - you're talking to people that don't want to talk to you. This can be challenging when trying to raise donations.

pros: Egalitarian culture throughout campus, and faculty members and staff participate in important decisions such as hiring and promotion. Students have sense of community and ownership
cons: Egalitarian culture throughout campus which may have discourage people to deliver high performance. People tend to shirk especially after obtaining tenure. Limited research and travel funding for research active faculty

pros: The atmosphere and people are nice, with a great location and lots of amenities in the city.
cons: Very little career path help, and some managers are unwilling to provide training for your career.  It can feel isolating working in one building and not need to visit other parts of campus.

review_title: A life-changing learning experience that I would not have traded for the world!
